column2: Cosette fled, dragging her pail, and taking the longest strides of which she was capable.
column3: Cosette fled, dragging her pail, and taking the longest strides of which she was capable.

column2: CHAPTER V--THE LITTLE ONE ALL ALONE
column3: CHAPTER five-THE LITTLE ONE ALL ALONE

column2: As the Thenardier hostelry was in that part of the village which is near the church, it was to the spring in the forest in the direction of Chelles that Cosette was obliged to go for her water.
column3: As the Thenardier hostelry was in that part of the village which is near the church, it was to the spring in the forest in the direction of Chelles that Cosette was obliged to go for her water.

column2: She did not glance at the display of a single other merchant.
column3: She did not glance at the display of a single other merchant.

column2: So long as she was in Boulanger Lane and in the neighborhood of the church, the lighted stalls illuminated the road; but soon the last light from the last stall vanished.
column3: So long as she was in Boulanger Lane and in the neighborhood of the church, the lighted stalls illuminated the road; but soon the last light from the last stall vanished.

column2: The poor child found herself in the dark.
column3: The poor child found herself in the dark.

column2: She plunged into it.
column3: She plunged into it.

column2: Only, as a certain emotion overcame her, she made as much motion as possible with the handle of the bucket as she walked along.
column3: Only, as a certain emotion overcame her, she made as much motion as possible with the handle of the bucket as she walked along.

column2: This made a noise which afforded her company.
column3: This made a noise which afforded her company.

column2: The further she went, the denser the darkness became.
column3: The further she went, the denser the darkness became.

column2: There was no one in the streets.
column3: There was no one in the streets.

column2: However, she did encounter a woman, who turned around on seeing her, and stood still, muttering between her teeth: "Where can that child be going?
column3: However, she did encounter a woman, who turned around on seeing her, and stood still, muttering between her teeth: "Where can that child be going?

column2: Is it a werewolf child?"
column3: Is it a werewolf child?"

column2: Then the woman recognized Cosette.
column3: Then the woman recognized Cosette.

column2: Well, said she, "it's the Lark!"
column3: Well, said she, "it's the Lark!"

column2: In this manner Cosette traversed the labyrinth of tortuous and deserted streets which terminate in the village of Montfermeil on the side of Chelles.
column3: In this manner Cosette traversed the labyrinth of tortuous and deserted streets which terminate in the village of Montfermeil on the side of Chelles.

column2: So long as she had the houses or even the walls only on both sides of her path, she proceeded with tolerable boldness.
column3: So long as she had the houses or even the walls only on both sides of her path, she proceeded with tolerable boldness.

column2: From time to time she caught the flicker of a candle through the crack of a shutter--this was light and life; there were people there, and it reassured her.
column3: From time to time she caught the flicker of a candle through the crack of a shutter-this was light and life; there were people there, and it reassured her.

column2: But in proportion as she advanced, her pace slackened mechanically, as it were.
column3: But in proportion as she advanced, her pace slackened mechanically, as it were.

column2: When she had passed the corner of the last house, Cosette paused.
column3: When she had passed the corner of the last house, Cosette paused.

column2: It had been hard to advance further than the last stall; it became impossible to proceed further than the last house.
column3: It had been hard to advance further than the last stall; it became impossible to proceed further than the last house.

column2: She set her bucket on the ground, thrust her hand into her hair, and began slowly to scratch her head,--a gesture peculiar to children when terrified and undecided what to do.
column3: She set her bucket on the ground, thrust her hand into her hair, and began slowly to scratch her head,--a gesture peculiar to children when terrified and undecided what to do.

column2: It was no longer Montfermeil; it was the open fields.
column3: It was no longer Montfermeil; it was the open fields.

column2: Black and desert space was before her.
column3: Black and desert space was before her.

column2: She gazed in despair at that darkness, where there was no longer any one, where there were beasts, where there were spectres, possibly.
column3: She gazed in despair at that darkness, where there was no longer any one, where there were beasts, where there were spectres, possibly.

column2: She took a good look, and heard the beasts walking on the grass, and she distinctly saw spectres moving in the trees.
column3: She took a good look, and heard the beasts walking on the grass, and she distinctly saw spectres moving in the trees.

column2: Then she seized her bucket again; fear had lent her audacity.
column3: Then she seized her bucket again; fear had lent her audacity.

column2: Bah! said she; "I will tell him that there was no more water!" And she resolutely re-entered Montfermeil.
column3: Bah! said she; "I will tell him that there was no more water!" And she resolutely re-entered Montfermeil.

column2: Hardly had she gone a hundred paces when she paused and began to scratch her head again.
column3: Hardly had she gone a hundred paces when she paused and began to scratch her head again.

column2: Now it was the Thenardier who appeared to her, with her hideous, hyena mouth, and wrath flashing in her eyes.
column3: Now it was the Thenardier who appeared to her, with her hideous, hyena mouth, and wrath flashing in her eyes.

column2: The child cast a melancholy glance before her and behind her.
column3: The child cast a melancholy glance before her and behind her.

column2: What was she to do?
column3: What was she to do?

column2: What was to become of her?
column3: What was to become of her?

column2: Where was she to go?
column3: Where was she to go?

column2: In front of her was the spectre of the Thenardier; behind her all the phantoms of the night and of the forest.
column3: In front of her was the spectre of the Thenardier; behind her all the phantoms of the night and of the forest.

column2: It was before the Thenardier that she recoiled.
column3: It was before the Thenardier that she recoiled.

column2: She resumed her path to the spring, and began to run.
column3: She resumed her path to the spring, and began to run.

column2: She emerged from the village, she entered the forest at a run, no longer looking at or listening to anything.
column3: She emerged from the village, she entered the forest at a run, no longer looking at or listening to anything.

column2: She only paused in her course when her breath failed her; but she did not halt in her advance.
column3: She only paused in her course when her breath failed her; but she did not halt in her advance.

column2: She went straight before her in desperation.
column3: She went straight before her in desperation.

column2: As she ran she felt like crying.
column3: As she ran she felt like crying.

column2: The nocturnal quivering of the forest surrounded her completely.
column3: The nocturnal quivering of the forest surrounded her completely.

column2: She no longer thought, she no longer saw.
column3: She no longer thought, she no longer saw.

column2: The immensity of night was facing this tiny creature.
column3: The immensity of night was facing this tiny creature.

column2: On the one hand, all shadow; on the other, an atom.
column3: On the one hand, all shadow; on the other, an atom.

column2: It was only seven or eight minutes' walk from the edge of the woods to the spring.
column3: It was only seven or eight minutes' walk from the edge of the woods to the spring.

column2: Cosette knew the way, through having gone over it many times in daylight.
column3: Cosette knew the way, through having gone over it many times in daylight.

column2: Strange to say, she did not get lost.
column3: Strange to say, she did not get lost.

column2: A remnant of instinct guided her vaguely.
column3: A remnant of instinct guided her vaguely.

column2: But she did not turn her eyes either to right or to left, for fear of seeing things in the branches and in the brushwood.
column3: But she did not turn her eyes either to right or to left, for fear of seeing things in the branches and in the brushwood.

column2: In this manner she reached the spring.
column3: In this manner she reached the spring.

column2: It was a narrow, natural basin, hollowed out by the water in a clayey soil, about two feet deep, surrounded with moss and with those tall, crimped grasses which are called Henry IV.'s frills, and paved with several large stones.
column3: It was a narrow, natural basin, hollowed out by the water in a clayey soil, about two feet deep, surrounded with moss and with those tall, crimped grasses which are called Henry the fourth's frills, and paved with several large stones.

column2: A brook ran out of it, with a tranquil little noise.
column3: A brook ran out of it, with a tranquil little noise.

column2: Cosette did not take time to breathe.
column3: Cosette did not take time to breathe.

column2: It was very dark, but she was in the habit of coming to this spring.
column3: It was very dark, but she was in the habit of coming to this spring.

column2: She felt with her left hand in the dark for a young oak which leaned over the spring, and which usually served to support her, found one of its branches, clung to it, bent down, and plunged the bucket in the water.
column3: She felt with her left hand in the dark for a young oak which leaned over the spring, and which usually served to support her, found one of its branches, clung to it, bent down, and plunged the bucket in the water.

column2: She was in a state of such violent excitement that her strength was trebled.
column3: She was in a state of such violent excitement that her strength was trebled.

column2: While thus bent over, she did not notice that the pocket of her apron had emptied itself into the spring.
column3: While thus bent over, she did not notice that the pocket of her apron had emptied itself into the spring.

column2: The fifteen-sou piece fell into the water.
column3: The fifteen sou piece fell into the water.

column2: Cosette neither saw nor heard it fall.
column3: Cosette neither saw nor heard it fall.

column2: She drew out the bucket nearly full, and set it on the grass.
column3: She drew out the bucket nearly full, and set it on the grass.

column2: That done, she perceived that she was worn out with fatigue.
column3: That done, she perceived that she was worn out with fatigue.

column2: She would have liked to set out again at once, but the effort required to fill the bucket had been such that she found it impossible to take a step.
column3: She would have liked to set out again at once, but the effort required to fill the bucket had been such that she found it impossible to take a step.

column2: She was forced to sit down.
column3: She was forced to sit down.

column2: She dropped on the grass, and remained crouching there.
column3: She dropped on the grass, and remained crouching there.

column2: She shut her eyes; then she opened them again, without knowing why, but because she could not do otherwise.
column3: She shut her eyes; then she opened them again, without knowing why, but because she could not do otherwise.

column2: The agitated water in the bucket beside her was describing circles which resembled tin serpents.
column3: The agitated water in the bucket beside her was describing circles which resembled tin serpents.

column2: Overhead the sky was covered with vast black clouds, which were like masses of smoke.
column3: Overhead the sky was covered with vast black clouds, which were like masses of smoke.

column2: The tragic mask of shadow seemed to bend vaguely over the child.
column3: The tragic mask of shadow seemed to bend vaguely over the child.

column2: Jupiter was setting in the depths.
column3: Jupiter was setting in the depths.

column2: The child stared with bewildered eyes at this great star, with which she was unfamiliar, and which terrified her.
column3: The child stared with bewildered eyes at this great star, with which she was unfamiliar, and which terrified her.

column2: The planet was, in fact, very near the horizon and was traversing a dense layer of mist which imparted to it a horrible ruddy hue.
column3: The planet was, in fact, very near the horizon and was traversing a dense layer of mist which imparted to it a horrible ruddy hue.

column2: The mist, gloomily empurpled, magnified the star.
column3: The mist, gloomily empurpled, magnified the star.

column2: One would have called it a luminous wound.
column3: One would have called it a luminous wound.

column2: A cold wind was blowing from the plain.
column3: A cold wind was blowing from the plain.

column2: The forest was dark, not a leaf was moving; there were none of the vague, fresh gleams of summertide. Great boughs uplifted themselves in frightful wise.
column3: The forest was dark, not a leaf was moving; there were none of the vague, fresh gleams of summertide. Great boughs uplifted themselves in frightful wise.

column2: Slender and misshapen bushes whistled in the clearings.
column3: Slender and misshapen bushes whistled in the clearings.

column2: The tall grasses undulated like eels under the north wind.
column3: The tall grasses undulated like eels under the north wind.

column2: The nettles seemed to twist long arms furnished with claws in search of prey.
column3: The nettles seemed to twist long arms furnished with claws in search of prey.

column2: Some bits of dry heather, tossed by the breeze, flew rapidly by, and had the air of fleeing in terror before something which was coming after.
column3: Some bits of dry heather, tossed by the breeze, flew rapidly by, and had the air of fleeing in terror before something which was coming after.

column2: On all sides there were lugubrious stretches.
column3: On all sides there were lugubrious stretches.

column2: The darkness was bewildering.
column3: The darkness was bewildering.

column2: Man requires light.
column3: Man requires light.

column2: Whoever buries himself in the opposite of day feels his heart contract.
column3: Whoever buries himself in the opposite of day feels his heart contract.

column2: When the eye sees black, the heart sees trouble.
column3: When the eye sees black, the heart sees trouble.

column2: In an eclipse in the night, in the sooty opacity, there is anxiety even for the stoutest of hearts.
column3: In an eclipse in the night, in the sooty opacity, there is anxiety even for the stoutest of hearts.

column2: No one walks alone in the forest at night without trembling.
column3: No one walks alone in the forest at night without trembling.

column2: Shadows and trees--two formidable densities.
column3: Shadows and trees-two formidable densities.

column2: A chimerical reality appears in the indistinct depths.
column3: A chimerical reality appears in the indistinct depths.

column2: The inconceivable is outlined a few paces distant from you with a spectral clearness.
column3: The inconceivable is outlined a few paces distant from you with a spectral clearness.

column2: One beholds floating, either in space or in one's own brain, one knows not what vague and intangible thing, like the dreams of sleeping flowers.
column3: One beholds floating, either in space or in one's own brain, one knows not what vague and intangible thing, like the dreams of sleeping flowers.

column2: There are fierce attitudes on the horizon. One inhales the effluvia of the great black void.
column3: There are fierce attitudes on the horizon. One inhales the effluvia of the great black void.

column2: One is afraid to glance behind him, yet desirous of doing so.
column3: One is afraid to glance behind him, yet desirous of doing so.

column2: The cavities of night, things grown haggard, taciturn profiles which vanish when one advances, obscure dishevelments, irritated tufts, livid pools, the lugubrious reflected in the funereal, the sepulchral immensity of silence, unknown but possible beings, bendings of mysterious branches, alarming torsos of trees, long handfuls of quivering plants,--against all this one has no protection.
column3: The cavities of night, things grown haggard, taciturn profiles which vanish when one advances, obscure dishevelments, irritated tufts, livid pools, the lugubrious reflected in the funereal, the sepulchral immensity of silence, unknown but possible beings, bendings of mysterious branches, alarming torsos of trees, long handfuls of quivering plants,--against all this one has no protection.

column2: There is no hardihood which does not shudder and which does not feel the vicinity of anguish.
column3: There is no hardihood which does not shudder and which does not feel the vicinity of anguish.

column2: One is conscious of something hideous, as though one's soul were becoming amalgamated with the darkness.
column3: One is conscious of something hideous, as though one's soul were becoming amalgamated with the darkness.

column2: This penetration of the shadows is indescribably sinister in the case of a child.
column3: This penetration of the shadows is indescribably sinister in the case of a child.

column2: Forests are apocalypses, and the beating of the wings of a tiny soul produces a sound of agony beneath their monstrous vault.
column3: Forests are apocalypses, and the beating of the wings of a tiny soul produces a sound of agony beneath their monstrous vault.

column2: Without understanding her sensations, Cosette was conscious that she was seized upon by that black enormity of nature; it was no longer terror alone which was gaining possession of her; it was something more terrible even than terror; she shivered.
column3: Without understanding her sensations, Cosette was conscious that she was seized upon by that black enormity of nature; it was no longer terror alone which was gaining possession of her; it was something more terrible even than terror; she shivered.

column2: There are no words to express the strangeness of that shiver which chilled her to the very bottom of her heart; her eye grew wild; she thought she felt that she should not be able to refrain from returning there at the same hour on the morrow.
column3: There are no words to express the strangeness of that shiver which chilled her to the very bottom of her heart; her eye grew wild; she thought she felt that she should not be able to refrain from returning there at the same hour on the morrow.

column2: Then, by a sort of instinct, she began to count aloud, one, two, three, four, and so on up to ten, in order to escape from that singular state which she did not understand, but which terrified her, and, when she had finished, she began again; this restored her to a true perception of the things about her.
column3: Then, by a sort of instinct, she began to count aloud, one, two, three, four, and so on up to ten, in order to escape from that singular state which she did not understand, but which terrified her, and, when she had finished, she began again; this restored her to a true perception of the things about her.

column2: Her hands, which she had wet in drawing the water, felt cold; she rose; her terror, a natural and unconquerable terror, had returned: she had but one thought now,--to flee at full speed through the forest, across the fields to the houses, to the windows, to the lighted candles.
column3: Her hands, which she had wet in drawing the water, felt cold; she rose; her terror, a natural and unconquerable terror, had returned: she had but one thought now,--to flee at full speed through the forest, across the fields to the houses, to the windows, to the lighted candles.

column2: Her glance fell upon the water which stood before her; such was the fright which the Thenardier inspired in her, that she dared not flee without that bucket of water: she seized the handle with both hands; she could hardly lift the pail.
column3: Her glance fell upon the water which stood before her; such was the fright which the Thenardier inspired in her, that she dared not flee without that bucket of water: she seized the handle with both hands; she could hardly lift the pail.

column2: In this manner she advanced a dozen paces, but the bucket was full; it was heavy; she was forced to set it on the ground once more.
column3: In this manner she advanced a dozen paces, but the bucket was full; it was heavy; she was forced to set it on the ground once more.

column2: She took breath for an instant, then lifted the handle of the bucket again, and resumed her march, proceeding a little further this time, but again she was obliged to pause.
column3: She took breath for an instant, then lifted the handle of the bucket again, and resumed her march, proceeding a little further this time, but again she was obliged to pause.

column2: After some seconds of repose she set out again. She walked bent forward, with drooping head, like an old woman; the weight of the bucket strained and stiffened her thin arms.
column3: After some seconds of repose she set out again. She walked bent forward, with drooping head, like an old woman; the weight of the bucket strained and stiffened her thin arms.

column2: The iron handle completed the benumbing and freezing of her wet and tiny hands; she was forced to halt from time to time, and each time that she did so, the cold water which splashed from the pail fell on her bare legs.
column3: The iron handle completed the benumbing and freezing of her wet and tiny hands; she was forced to halt from time to time, and each time that she did so, the cold water which splashed from the pail fell on her bare legs.

column2: This took place in the depths of a forest, at night, in winter, far from all human sight; she was a child of eight: no one but God saw that sad thing at the moment.
column3: This took place in the depths of a forest, at night, in winter, far from all human sight; she was a child of eight: no one but God saw that sad thing at the moment.

column2: And her mother, no doubt, alas!
column3: And her mother, no doubt, alas!

column2: For there are things that make the dead open their eyes in their graves.
column3: For there are things that make the dead open their eyes in their graves.

column2: She panted with a sort of painful rattle; sobs contracted her throat, but she dared not weep, so afraid was she of the Thenardier, even at a distance: it was her custom to imagine the Thenardier always present.
column3: She panted with a sort of painful rattle; sobs contracted her throat, but she dared not weep, so afraid was she of the Thenardier, even at a distance: it was her custom to imagine the Thenardier always present.

column2: However, she could not make much headway in that manner, and she went on very slowly.
column3: However, she could not make much headway in that manner, and she went on very slowly.

column2: In spite of diminishing the length of her stops, and of walking as long as possible between them, she reflected with anguish that it would take her more than an hour to return to Montfermeil in this manner, and that the Thenardier would beat her.
column3: In spite of diminishing the length of her stops, and of walking as long as possible between them, she reflected with anguish that it would take her more than an hour to return to Montfermeil in this manner, and that the Thenardier would beat her.

column2: This anguish was mingled with her terror at being alone in the woods at night; she was worn out with fatigue, and had not yet emerged from the forest.
column3: This anguish was mingled with her terror at being alone in the woods at night; she was worn out with fatigue, and had not yet emerged from the forest.

column2: On arriving near an old chestnut-tree with which she was acquainted, made a last halt, longer than the rest, in order that she might get well rested; then she summoned up all her strength, picked up her bucket again, and courageously resumed her march, but the poor little desperate creature could not refrain from crying, "O my God! my God!"
column3: On arriving near an old chestnut tree with which she was acquainted, made a last halt, longer than the rest, in order that she might get well rested; then she summoned up all her strength, picked up her bucket again, and courageously resumed her march, but the poor little desperate creature could not refrain from crying, "O my God! my God!"

column2: At that moment she suddenly became conscious that her bucket no longer weighed anything at all: a hand, which seemed to her enormous, had just seized the handle, and lifted it vigorously.
column3: At that moment she suddenly became conscious that her bucket no longer weighed anything at all: a hand, which seemed to her enormous, had just seized the handle, and lifted it vigorously.

column2: She raised her head.
column3: She raised her head.

column2: A large black form, straight and erect, was walking beside her through the darkness; it was a man who had come up behind her, and whose approach she had not heard.
column3: A large black form, straight and erect, was walking beside her through the darkness; it was a man who had come up behind her, and whose approach she had not heard.

column2: This man, without uttering a word, had seized the handle of the bucket which she was carrying.
column3: This man, without uttering a word, had seized the handle of the bucket which she was carrying.

column2: There are instincts for all the encounters of life.
column3: There are instincts for all the encounters of life.

column2: The child was not afraid.
column3: The child was not afraid.

column2: CHAPTER VI--WHICH POSSIBLY PROVES BOULATRUELLE'S INTELLIGENCE
column3: CHAPTER six-WHICH POSSIBLY PROVES BOULATRUELLE'S INTELLIGENCE
